justification: The article states that "In the psychological literature these problems are often studied using multi-armed bandit problems," indicating that researchers use the multi-armed bandit task as the empirical tool for assessing exploration–exploitation decisions.

measured_by: vanishing-options ‘doors’ task (variation of a three-armed bandit)
justification: Referring to Shin & Ariely (2004), the paper explains that they "presented people with a variation of the three-armed bandit task" in which unchosen options could "vanish," and that participants' reluctance to let options disappear indexed their aversion to option loss.

The authors compare human behaviour "to a standard restless bandit task in which options do not vanish," using that dynamic bandit paradigm to measure how people adapt their decisions when reward distributions drift over time.
